articles.headline: Marquee Writers Push for Negotiations, but Their Clout May Not Matter
articles.snippet: Some showrunners, eager for progress in the Hollywood strike, want the Writers Guild of America to meet with studios. How much sway they still have is in question.
articles.abstract: Some showrunners, eager for progress in the Hollywood strike, want the Writers Guild of America to meet with studios. How much sway they still have is in question.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the Hollywood writers’ strike stretching into its fifth month and the financial toll on people across the entertainment industry becoming increasingly grim, A-list showrunners have grown impatient.
articles.byline: By John Koblin, Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: U.A.W. Prepares for Limited Strike Against Detroit Automakers on Friday
articles.snippet: The union’s president, Shawn Fain, said negotiators were nowhere near an agreement and ruled out a contract extension while talks continued.
articles.abstract: The union’s president, Shawn Fain, said negotiators were nowhere near an agreement and ruled out a contract extension while talks continued.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barely 24 hours before the contract deadline, the United Auto Workers leader said Wednesday that his members were prepared for a strike against the three Detroit automakers — first at a limited number of factories, with the walkout expanding if talks remain bogged down.

articles.headline: History Turns Upside Down in a War Where the Koreas Are Suppliers
articles.snippet: Desperate for munitions for the war in Ukraine, the U.S. and Russia have turned to their allies in South and North Korea, which kept stockpiling arms for decades after their own conflict.
articles.abstract: Desperate for munitions for the war in Ukraine, the U.S. and Russia have turned to their allies in South and North Korea, which kept stockpiling arms for decades after their own conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: Washington and Moscow flooded the Korean Peninsula with arms and aid as they fueled the war between South and North seven decades ago. Now, in a fateful moment of history turning back on itself, Russia and the United States are reaching out to those same allies to supply badly needed munitions as the powers face each other down again, this time on the other side of the globe, in Ukraine.

articles.headline: Bernard Arnault Built a Luxury Empire on ‘Desirability.’ Who Will Inherit It?
articles.snippet: With brands like Tiffany, Dom Pérignon and Louis Vuitton, LVMH turned him into one of the world’s richest men. But with five children, he has a hard decision to make.
articles.abstract: With brands like Tiffany, Dom Pérignon and Louis Vuitton, LVMH turned him into one of the world’s richest men. But with five children, he has a hard decision to make.
articles.lead_paragraph: One afternoon in July, not long after being named the wealthiest man on the planet by Forbes, Bernard Arnault, the head of the LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton luxury goods empire, took his place on a stage with a view of the Eiffel Tower before a packed crowd of French dignitaries and reporters.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Vanessa Friedman

articles.headline: Meet the Man Making Big Banks Tremble
articles.snippet: Michael Barr, whom President Biden appointed as the Federal Reserve’s top bank cop, has drawn blowback for his bank regulation push.
articles.abstract: Michael Barr, whom President Biden appointed as the Federal Reserve’s top bank cop, has drawn blowback for his bank regulation push.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yelling at Michael Barr, the Federal Reserve’s top banking regulator, has never been particularly effective, his friends and co-workers will tell you. That hasn’t stopped America’s biggest banks, their lobbying groups and even his own colleagues, who have reacted to his proposal to tighten and expand oversight of the nation’s large lenders with a mix of incredulity and outrage.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: Instacart Was All About Grocery Delivery. No Longer.
articles.snippet: As it prepares to go public next week, Instacart shows that one secret to making money as a gig economy company is to become an advertising company.
articles.abstract: As it prepares to go public next week, Instacart shows that one secret to making money as a gig economy company is to become an advertising company.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Fidji Simo took over as chief executive of Instacart in 2021, the grocery delivery start-up’s growth was cratering as its pandemic boom ebbed. The board of directors asked her to find new ways for the company to earn money.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Cable TV Is on Life Support, but a New Bundle Is Coming Alive
articles.snippet: Cable companies have started to figure out a way to stay in the TV game: Reselling streaming services.
articles.abstract: Cable companies have started to figure out a way to stay in the TV game: Reselling streaming services.
articles.lead_paragraph: A funny thing happened in recent weeks, as the media industry wrung its hands over the long-anticipated death of the lucrative cable-TV bundle: Hundreds of thousands of people turned to a different bundle.

articles.headline: Arm Soars 25% in the Year’s Biggest Initial Public Offering
articles.snippet: The performance of the British chip designer’s shares signals that the I.P.O. market may revive after a very quiet year.
articles.abstract: The performance of the British chip designer’s shares signals that the I.P.O. market may revive after a very quiet year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Call it Wall Street’s Groundhog Day.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Don Clark

articles.headline: ‘A Ticket to Disney’? Politicians Charge Millions to Send Migrants to U.S.
articles.snippet: The Biden administration vowed to “end the illicit movement” of people through the Darién jungle. But the number of migrants moving through the forest has never been greater — and the profits are too big to pass up.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration vowed to “end the illicit movement” of people through the Darién jungle. But the number of migrants moving through the forest has never been greater — and the profits are too big to pass up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every step through the jungle, there is money to be made.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios

articles.headline: C.I.A. Discloses Identity of Second Spy Involved in ‘Argo’ Operation
articles.snippet: The movie about the daring mission to rescue American diplomats from Tehran portrayed a single C.I.A. officer sneaking into the Iranian capital. In reality, the agency sent two officers.
articles.abstract: The movie about the daring mission to rescue American diplomats from Tehran portrayed a single C.I.A. officer sneaking into the Iranian capital. In reality, the agency sent two officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the midst of the 1979 Iran hostage crisis, the C.I.A. began what came to be noted as one of the spy agency’s most successful publicly known operations: the rescue of six American diplomats who had escaped the overrun U.S. Embassy — using a fake movie as the cover story.
